<script type="text/javascript">
var main_site_url = 'https://www.paloaltonetworks.com';
var maindomain_lang = 'https://www.paloaltonetworks.com';
function getParameterByName(name, url) {
		if(url == null){
		  url = window.location.href;
		}
	    name = name.replace(/[\[\]]/g, '\\$&');
	    var regex = new RegExp('[?&]' + name + '(=([^&#]*)|&|#|$)'),
		results = regex.exec(url);
	    if (!results) return null;
	    if (!results[2]) return '';
	    return decodeURIComponent(results[2].replace(/\+/g, ' '));
	}
	var container_q = getParameterByName('container');
	var d_lang = 'en';	
	if(container_q != '' && container_q != null){	    
	    sessionStorage.setItem('container',container_q);
	    	    location.href = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/bianlian-ransomware-group-threat-assessment';
	}
</script>

<meta property="og:category_link" content="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/cybercrime/"/>
<meta property="og:category_link" content="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/top-cyberthreats/"/>
<meta property="og:category_link" content="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/ransomware/"/>
<meta property="og:author" content="Daniel Frank"/>
<meta property="og:authorlink" content="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/author/"/>
<meta property="og:author_image_link" content="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/11/unit-news-meta.svg"/>
<meta name="post_tags" content="BianLian,Bitter Scorpius,Makop"/>
<meta property="og:post_image" content="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/01/Ransomware-r3d1.png"/>
<script type="application/ld+json">{"@context":"https:\/\/schema.org","@type":"BlogPosting","headline":"Threat Assessment: BianLian","name":"Threat Assessment: BianLian","description":"We analyze the extremely active ransomware group BianLian. Mostly targeting healthcare, they have moved from double-extortion to extortion without encryption.","url":"https:\/\/unit42.paloaltonetworks.com\/bianlian-ransomware-group-threat-assessment\/","mainEntityOfPage":"https:\/\/unit42.paloaltonetworks.com\/bianlian-ransomware-group-threat-assessment\/","datePublished":"January 23, 2024","articleBody":"Executive Summary\r\nUnit 42 researchers have been tracking the BianLian ransomware group, which has been in the top 10 of the most active groups based on leak site data we\u2019ve gathered. From that leak site data, we\u2019ve primarily observed activity affecting the healthcare and manufacturing sectors and industries, and impacting organizations mainly in the United States (US) and Europe (EU).\r\n\r\nWe also observed that the BianLian group shares a small, customized tool in common with the Makop ransomware group. This shared tool indicates a possible connection between the two groups, which we will explore further.\r\n\r\nBianLian has also recently moved from a double extortion scheme to one of extortion without encryption. Rather than encrypting their victims\u2019 assets before stealing data and threatening to publish it if they do not pay the ransom, they\u2019re now moving straight to stealing data to motivate victims to pay.\r\n\r\nThe Unit 42 Incident Response team has responded to several BianLian ransomware incidents since September 2022.\r\n\r\nPalo Alto Networks customers are better protected against ransomware used by the BianLian ransomware group through Cortex XDR, as well as by Cloud-Delivered Security Services for the Next-Generation Firewall such as WildFire and Advanced URL Filtering.\r\n\r\nIn particular, the Cortex XDR anti-ransomware module included out-of-the-box protections that prevented adverse behavior from the ransomware samples we tested without the need for specific detection logic or signatures.\r\n\r\nThe Prisma Cloud Defender should be deployed on cloud-based Windows virtual machines to ensure they are protected. Cortex Xpanse is able to provide visibility that can prove valuable for proactive protection.\r\n\r\nThe Unit 42 Incident Response team can also be engaged to help with a compromise or to provide a proactive assessment to lower your risk.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nRelated Unit 42 Topics\r\nRansomware, Cybercrime\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nBianLian Threat Overview\r\nThe BianLian group has been extremely active ever since it emerged in 2022, with new organizations compromised by the group being reported on their leak site almost on a weekly basis. Figure 1 below details their activity throughout 2023, as illustrated by their leak site data.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_132128\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"900\"] Figure 1. Activity of the BianLian group throughout 2023.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nThis group impacts mainly the healthcare, manufacturing, professional and legal services sectors. Their attacks have primarily taken place in North America, but they were also seen in the EU and India.\r\n\r\nBianLian shares a small custom .NET tool with the Makop ransomware group, which indicates a possible connection between the two groups.\r\n\r\nBianLian has moved from a double extortion scheme of encrypting their victims\u2019 assets, stealing data, and threatening to publish it if they do not pay the ransom to a main focus of extortion without encryption.\r\n\r\nThe group\u2019s leak site indicates that BianLian might be expanding by hiring new developers and affiliates, as noted in the \u201cWork with us\u201d section from the group's homepage shown below in Figure 2.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_132130\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"800\"] Figure 2. The BianLian leak site homepage, late December 2023.[\/caption]The BianLian group regularly updates the list of compromised targets on their leak site. Figure 3 details the most affected countries. While BianLian has impacted organizations all over the world, the US is clearly the most affected country as of 2023.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_132132\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"900\"] Figure 3. A map showing the countries impacted by BianLian in 2023.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nAs detailed in Figure 4 below, healthcare is the sector most affected by the BianLian group, with manufacturing a close second. In January 2023, the group claimed to have exfiltrated 1.7 TB of data, including personal data of patients and employees, from a California-based hospital. Attacks on healthcare organizations are especially concerning because they disrupt hospitals\u2019 day-to-day operations and potentially endanger patients' lives.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_132134\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"900\"] Figure 4. The distribution of the sectors that BianLian attacked in 2023.[\/caption]\r\nPossible Connection to Makop Ransomware\r\nDuring our analysis, we noticed a small .NET custom executable was shared between the BianLian and Makop ransomware groups. Both groups also used the same hash of the publicly available Advanced Port Scanner tool.\r\n\r\nThis .NET tool is responsible for retrieving file enumeration, registry and clipboard data. This tool contains some words in the Russian language, such as the numbers one to four. The use of such a tool indicates that the two groups might have shared a tool set or used the services of the same developers in the past.\r\n\r\nA possible \u2013 yet not confirmed \u2013 explanation for this overlap is that BianLian could be sharing a codebase with the Makop group, or using the services of the same third-party developers. This phenomenon is well-known and documented among certain underground cybercrime groups.\r\n\r\nAnother noteworthy fact is that the Makop ransomware was documented excluding certain file extensions when encrypting an infected endpoint, including known extensions that are used by other ransomware strains. This is yet another indicator of possible existing relationships among these threat actors, or at least a \u201cnot stepping on someone\u2019s toes\u201d approach when it involves other ransomware groups.\r\nTechnical Analysis\r\nAttack Lifecycle\r\nWe have mapped the attack stages that are common with the BianLian group to the MITRE ATT&amp;CK framework, which is summarized below.\r\nInitial Access\r\nTo infiltrate corporate networks, BianLian operators often perform the following activities:\r\n\r\n \tUse stolen Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP) credentials\r\n \tExploit the ProxyShell vulnerability\r\n \tTarget virtual private network (VPN) providers\r\n \tUse other previously reported techniques such as deploying web shells\r\n\r\nDuring the last year, BianLian\u2019s methods of infiltration and lateral movement did not change much. Nevertheless, we were able to retrieve interesting forensic data from our telemetry that provides additional behavioral indicators of compromise (IoCs).\r\n\r\nAfter successfully infiltrating an organization\u2019s network, our telemetry indicates the BianLian group uses various public tools to move laterally, dump credentials and remotely execute a backdoor payload.\r\nCredential Dumping\r\nIn our telemetry, we have witnessed dumping of the Security Accounts Manager (SAM) registry hive into a file at %windir%\\Temp. This is a common technique used by attackers.\r\n\r\nThe SAM stores hashed passwords from accounts used on the attacked machine, and it can be recovered when processing SYSTEM privileges. The corresponding Cortex XDR alert is shown in Figure 5.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_132136\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"900\"] Figure 5. SAM dumping alert in Cortex XDR.[\/caption]\r\nPersistence\r\nDuring the analysis of our telemetry, we saw the attackers drop the BianLian backdoor DLL component under the following path:\r\n\r\n \tc:\\\\programdata\\\\vmware\\\\[filename].dll.\r\n\r\nTo execute the backdoor, they used the impacket tool to create the following scheduled task:\r\ncmd.exe \/C rundll32.exe\r\nc:\\\\programdata\\\\vmware\\\\[filename].dll,Entry &gt;\r\nC:\\\\Windows\\\\Temp\\\\[filename].tmp 2&gt;&amp;1.\r\nThe creation of the task was detected by Cortex XDR, and the corresponding alert is shown in Figure 6 below.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_132138\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"900\"] Figure 6. The impacket task creation alert in Cortex XDR.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nThis task\u2019s role is to periodically execute the backdoor DLL with its export function named Entry, using rundll32. The execution of the backdoor DLL was detected and prevented by Cortex XDR. The alert and prevention pop-up are shown in Figures 7 and 8, respectively.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_132140\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"900\"] Figure 7. The backdoor execution detection by Cortex XDR in detect mode.[\/caption]\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_132142\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"500\"] Figure 8. The backdoor execution prevention by Cortex XDR in prevent mode.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nThe backdoors themselves have different names and paths in each incident, thus making it difficult to implement naming-based behavioral detection.\r\nReconnaissance\r\nTo get a better picture of an already infected network\u2019s open ports that attackers can later use for lateral movement, the tool Advanced Port Scanner by Famatech was used from the following path:\r\n\r\n \tC:\\\\Users\\\\%username%\\\\AppData\\\\Local\\\\Temp\\\\31\\\\Advanced_Port_Scanner_2.5.3869.exe\r\n\r\nThis is the same Advanced Port Scanner file that Makop ransomware was previously documented using. The alerts raised by its execution are shown in Figure 9.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_132144\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"900\"] Figure 9. Alerts raised by the execution of Advanced Port Scanner.[\/caption]\r\nEncryptor and Backdoor\r\nSince the beginning of their activity, BianLian used two main components for their final payloads: an encryptor and a backdoor. Figure 10 below shows the encryptor\u2019s ransom note.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_132146\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"700\"] Figure 10. Example of a ransom note generated by a BianLian encryptor first seen in April 2023.[\/caption]In early 2023, Avast released a decryptor for BianLian's encryptor, which ultimately caused the group to cease most of its encryption activity. The threat actors then shifted their operation into a steal-and-extort scheme, mainly relying on their custom backdoor.\r\n\r\nBianLian's backdoor, similar to the encryptor, is written in Go. Its core functionality is more of a loader than a classic backdoor, with its main functionality being downloading and executing additional payloads. The backdoor contains a hard-coded C2 IP address and port to communicate with.\r\n\r\nAs shown in Figures 11 and 12, Cortex XDR successfully detected the execution of the encryptor, using its anti-ransomware module and other behavioral and static detection signatures.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_132148\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"500\"] Figure 11. BianLian encryptor detection by Cortex XDR in detect mode.[\/caption]\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_132150\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"900\"] Figure 12. Alerts raised by Cortex XDR detecting the BianLian encryptor in detect mode.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nAs shown in Figure 13, when operating in prevent mode, the BianLian encryptor is prevented by Cortex XDR.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_132152\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"400\"] Figure 13. The BianLian encryptor is prevented by Cortex XDR in prevent mode.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nFigures 14 and 15 below demonstrate how Cortex XDR also detected the BianLian custom backdoor in detect mode and prevented it in prevent mode.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_132154\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"400\"] Figure 14. Cortex XDR detecting the BianLian backdoor in detect mode.[\/caption]\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_132156\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"400\"] Figure 15. The BianLian backdoor is prevented by Cortex XDR in prevent mode.[\/caption]\r\nConclusion\r\nFollowing its discovery in 2022, the BianLian group has been one of the most active and prevalent extortion groups in the cyberthreat landscape. Out of the leak site data tracked by Unit 42 between January and mid-December of 2023, BianLian was in the top 10 of the most active groups. There is a growing list of alleged victims that they update on their leak site.\r\n\r\nMaintaining their tactics, techniques and procedures (TTPs) of infiltrating corporate networks, the BianLian group has shown adaptiveness to the ransomware market demands. They have shifted from double-extortion into being focused solely on extortion efforts, pressuring their victims into paying the ransom without encrypting their files. A possible connection to the Makop ransomware group was also found, due to their mutual use of a custom tool.\r\nProtections and Mitigations\r\nSmartScore, a unique ML-driven scoring engine that translates security investigation methods and their associated data into a hybrid scoring system, scored an incident involving BianLian backdoor at 91 out of 100, as shown in Figure 16. This type of scoring helps analysts determine which incidents are more urgent and provides context about the reason for the assessment, assisting with prioritization.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_132158\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"565\"] Figure 16. SmartScore information about a BianLian backdoor incident.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nPalo Alto Networks customers are better protected from the BianLian encryptor and backdoor components.\r\n\r\nThe Cortex XDR and XSIAM platforms detect and prevent the execution flow described in the screenshots included in the previous section.\r\n\r\nThe Cortex XDR agent included out of the box protections that prevented adverse behavior from the samples we tested from this group, without the need for specific detection logic or signatures.\r\n\r\nCortex XDR and XSIAM detect user- and credential-based threats by analyzing user activity from multiple data sources including the following:\r\n\r\n \tEndpoints\r\n \tNetwork firewalls\r\n \tActive Directory\r\n \tIdentity and access management solutions\r\n \tCloud workloads\r\n\r\nCortex XDR and XSIAM build behavioral profiles of user activity over time with machine learning. By comparing new activity to past activity, peer activity and the expected behavior of the entity, Cortex XDR and XSIAM detect anomalous activity indicative of credential-based attacks.\r\n\r\nThey also offer the following protections related to the attacks discussed in this post:\r\n\r\n \tPrevent the execution of known malicious malware\r\n \tPrevent execution of unknown malware using Behavioral Threat Protection and machine learning based on the Local Analysis module\r\n \tProtect against credential-gathering tools and techniques using the Credential Gathering Protection, available from Cortex XDR 3.4\r\n \tProtect against exploitation of different vulnerabilities including ProxyShell using the Anti-Exploitation modules as well as Behavioral Threat Protection\r\n\r\nCortex XDR Pro detects post-exploitation activity, including credential-based attacks, with behavioral analytics.\r\n\r\nThe Prisma Cloud Defender as well as Cortex XDR for cloud agents should be deployed on cloud-based Windows virtual machines to ensure they are protected from these known malicious binaries. WildFire signatures can be used by both Palo Alto Networks cloud services to ensure cloud-based Windows virtual machine runtime operations are being analyzed and those resources are protected.\r\n\r\nCloud-Delivered Security Services for the Next-Generation Firewall such as WildFire and Advanced URL Filtering include protections based on the IoCs shared in this article.\r\n\r\nCortex Xpanse is also able to detect exposed RDP and many other remote access interfaces which are often brute forced or exploited with compromised credentials. This visibility can prove valuable through proactive prevention.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_132160\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"900\"] Figure 17. A subset of the exposed remote access interface types that Cortex Xpanse can detect.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nIf you think you might have been impacted or have an urgent matter, get in touch with the Unit 42 Incident Response team or call:\r\n\r\n \tNorth America Toll-Free: 866.486.4842 (866.4.UNIT42)\r\n \tEMEA: +31.20.299.3130\r\n \tAPAC: +65.6983.8730\r\n \tJapan: +81.50.1790.0200\r\n\r\nPalo Alto Networks has shared these findings with our fellow Cyber Threat Alliance (CTA) members. CTA members use this intelligence to rapidly deploy protections to their customers and to systematically disrupt malicious cyber actors. Learn more about the Cyber Threat Alliance.\r\nIndicators of Compromise\r\nExamples of the BianLian Encryptor\r\n\r\n \taf46356eb70f0fbb0799f8a8d5c0f7513d2f6ade4f16d4869f2690029b511d4f\r\n \t1fd42d07b4be99e0e503c0ed5af2274312be1b03e01b54a6d89c0eef04257d6e\r\n \t3a2f6e614ff030804aa18cb03fcc3bc357f6226786efb4a734cbe2a3a1984b6f\r\n \t46d340eaf6b78207e24b6011422f1a5b4a566e493d72365c6a1cace11c36b28b\r\n \t1fd07b8d1728e416f897bef4f1471126f9b18ef108eb952f4b75050da22e8e43\r\n \teaf5e26c5e73f3db82cd07ea45e4d244ccb3ec3397ab5263a1a74add7bbcb6e2\r\n\r\nExamples of the BianLian Backdoor\r\n\r\n \tc775e6d87a3bcc5e94cd055fee859bdb6350af033114fe8588d2d4d4f6d2a3ae\r\n \tc57ca631b069745027d0b4f4d717821ca9bd095e28de2eafe4723eeaf4b062cf\r\n \tc592194cea0acf3d3e181d2ba3108f0f86d74bcd8e49457981423f5f902d054b\r\n \tdf51b7b031ecc7c7fa899e17cce98b005576a20a199be670569d5e408d21048c\r\n \t2ed448721f4e92c7970972f029290ee6269689c840a922982ac2f39c9a6a838f\r\n \t264af7e7aa17422eb4299df640c1aa199b4778509697b6b296efa5ae7e957b40\r\n \t73d095abf2f31358c8b1fb0d5a0dc9807e88d44282c896b5033c1b270d44111f\r\n \t8b65c9437445e9bcb8164d8557ecb9e3585c8bebf37099a3ec1437884efbdd24\r\n \t4ca84be5b6ab91694a0f81350cefe8379efcad692872a383671ce4209295edc7\r\n \t93fb7f0c2cf10fb5885e03c737ee8508816c1102e9e3d358160b78e91fa1ebdb\r\n \tafb7f11da27439a2e223e6b651f96eb16a7e35b34918e501886d25439015bf78\r\n \t53095e2ad802072e97dbb8a7ccea03a36d1536fce921c80a7a2f160c83366999\r\n \t16cbfd155fb44c6fd0f9375376f62a90ac09f8b7689c1afb5b9b4d3e76e28bdf\r\n \t60b1394f3afee27701e2008f46d766ef466caa7711c45ddfd443a71efc39a407\r\n \tba3c4bc99b67038b42b75a206d7ef04f6d8abaf87a76c373d4dec85e73859ce2\r\n \te7e097723d00f58eab785baf30365c1495e99aa6ead6fe1b86109558838d294e\r\n \t96e02ea8b1c508f1ee3c1535547f9b89396f557011e61478644ae5876cdaaca5\r\n \tac1d42360c45e0e908d07e784ceb15faf8987e4ba1744d56313de6524d2687f7\r\n \t1cba58f73221b5bb7930bfeab0106ae5415e70f49a595727022dcf6fda1126e9\r\n \t487f0d748a13570a46b20b6687eb7b7fc70a1a55e676fb5ff2599096a1ca888c\r\n \tf84edc07b23423f2c2cad47c0600133cab3cf2bd6072ad45649d6faf3b70ec30\r\n \t93953eef3fe8405d563560dc332135bfe5874ddeb373d714862f72ee62bef518\r\n \tf3f3c692f728b9c8fd2e1c090b60223ac6c6e88bf186c98ed9842408b78b9f3c\r\n <script>var $ = jQuery;</script>

    <script type="text/javascript">
    ;(function(win, doc, style, timeout) {
    var STYLE_ID = 'at-body-style';
    function getParent() {
    return doc.getElementsByTagName('head')[0];
    }
    function addStyle(parent, id, def) {
        if (!parent) {
        return;
        }
        var style = doc.createElement('style');
        style.id = id;
        style.innerHTML = def;
        parent.appendChild(style);
    }
    function removeStyle(parent, id) {
        if (!parent) {
            return;
        }
        var style = doc.getElementById(id);
        if (!style) {
            return;
        }
        parent.removeChild(style);
    }
    addStyle(getParent(), STYLE_ID, style);
    setTimeout(function() {
    removeStyle(getParent(), STYLE_ID);
    }, timeout);
    }(window, document, "body {visibility:hidden !important}", 3000));
    </script>

            <script src="https://assets.adobedtm.com/9273d4aedcd2/0d76ae0322d7/launch-425c423d843b.min.js" async></script>

<script type="text/javascript">
var isIE11 = !!navigator.userAgent.match(/Trident.*rv\:11\./);
if(isIE11){
    var polyfill = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/scripts/polyfill.min.js';
    document.write('<script type="text/javascript" src="'+polyfill+'">\x3C/script>');
}
    /**
 * String.prototype.replaceAll() polyfill
 * https://gomakethings.com/how-to-replace-a-section-of-a-string-with-another-one-with-vanilla-js/
 * @author Chris Ferdinandi
 * @license MIT
 */
if (!String.prototype.replaceAll) {
	String.prototype.replaceAll = function(str, newStr){
		// If a regex pattern
		if (Object.prototype.toString.call(str).toLowerCase() === '[object regexp]') {
			return this.replace(str, newStr);
		}
		// If a string
		return this.replace(new RegExp(str, 'g'), newStr);
	};
}

    /*! lozad.js - v1.16.0 - 2020-09-06 */
!function(t,e){"object"==typeof exports&&"undefined"!=typeof module?module.exports=e():"function"==typeof define&&define.amd?define(e):t.lozad=e()}(this,function(){"use strict";
/**
   * Detect IE browser
   * @const {boolean}
   * @private
   */var g="undefined"!=typeof document&&document.documentMode,f={rootMargin:"0px",threshold:0,load:function(t){if("picture"===t.nodeName.toLowerCase()){var e=t.querySelector("img"),r=!1;null===e&&(e=document.createElement("img"),r=!0),g&&t.getAttribute("data-iesrc")&&(e.src=t.getAttribute("data-iesrc")),t.getAttribute("data-alt")&&(e.alt=t.getAttribute("data-alt")),r&&t.append(e)}if("video"===t.nodeName.toLowerCase()&&!t.getAttribute("data-src")&&t.children){for(var a=t.children,o=void 0,i=0;i<=a.length-1;i++)(o=a[i].getAttribute("data-src"))&&(a[i].src=o);t.load()}t.getAttribute("data-poster")&&(t.poster=t.getAttribute("data-poster")),t.getAttribute("data-src")&&(t.src=t.getAttribute("data-src")),t.getAttribute("data-srcset")&&t.setAttribute("srcset",t.getAttribute("data-srcset"));var n=",";if(t.getAttribute("data-background-delimiter")&&(n=t.getAttribute("data-background-delimiter")),t.getAttribute("data-background-image"))t.style.backgroundImage="url('"+t.getAttribute("data-background-image").split(n).join("'),url('")+"')";else if(t.getAttribute("data-background-image-set")){var d=t.getAttribute("data-background-image-set").split(n),u=d[0].substr(0,d[0].indexOf(" "))||d[0];// Substring before ... 1x

</script>

<script type="text/javascript">
	function getCookie(cname) {
	 	var name = cname + "=";
  		var decodedCookie = decodeURIComponent(document.cookie);
		var ca = decodedCookie.split(';');
  		for(var i = 0; i <ca.length; i++) {
    			var c = ca[i];
    			while (c.charAt(0) == ' ') {
     				 c = c.substring(1);
    			}
    			if (c.indexOf(name) == 0) {
    				 return c.substring(name.length, c.length);
    			}
  		}
  		return "";
	}

	var referer = "";//sessionStorage.container;
	var pcontainer = sessionStorage.getItem("container");
	var searchResultsPagePath = "";
	if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Prisma')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Prisma' ;
	}
        else if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Cortex')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Cortex' ;
	}
        else if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Sase')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Sase' ;
	}
	else if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Unit')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Unit' ;
	}
	else if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Ngfw')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Ngfw' ;
	}
        var fromRef = document.referrer;
        var nContainer = getCookie("navContainer");
        if(nContainer){//If user is coming from main site, we need to reset the container		
		if(fromRef  && fromRef.indexOf("prismacloud.io")!=-1){
                        referer = 'Prisma' ;
                        sessionStorage.setItem("container","Prisma");
                } else if(fromRef.indexOf("paloaltonetworks.com")!=-1 || fromRef.indexOf("paloaltonetworks.jp")!=-1 ){
                        if(nContainer.indexOf('Prisma') != -1){
                            referer = 'Prisma' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Prisma");
                        }
                        if(nContainer.indexOf('Cortex') != -1){
                            referer = 'Cortex' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Cortex");
                        }
			if(nContainer.indexOf('Sase') != -1){
                            referer = 'Sase' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Sase");
                        }
			if(nContainer.indexOf('Unit') != -1){
                            referer = 'Unit' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Unit");
                        }
			if(nContainer.indexOf('Ngfw') != -1){
                            referer = 'Ngfw' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Ngfw");
                        }
			document.cookie = 'navContainer=; path=/; domain=.paloaltonetworks.com; expires=' + new Date(0).toUTCString();
		}
	}
if(referer != "Prisma" && referer != "Cortex" && referer != "Sase" && referer != "Unit" && referer != "Ngfw") {
    referer = 'Unit' ;
    sessionStorage.setItem("container","Unit");
}
function callMainSitePrismaNavHTML(){
    
    var referrer_domain = 'https://www.paloaltonetworks.com';
    sessionStorage.setItem("domain",referrer_domain);
    if(referer == 'Prisma'){
        var menu_url = referrer_domain+'/_jcr_content/globals/cleanHeaderPrisma.prismaRenderer.html';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/prismasearch";
        }
    if(referer == 'Cortex'){
        var menu_url = referrer_domain+'/_jcr_content/globals/cleanHeaderCortex.cortexRenderer.html';	
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/cortexsearch";	
    }
    if(referer == 'Sase'){
        var menu_url = referrer_domain+'/_jcr_content/globals/cleanHeaderSase.saseRenderer.html';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/sasesearch";
    }
    if(referer == 'Unit'){
        var menu_url = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/unit-nav-renderer.php';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/content/pan/en_US/search/unit42search";
		    }
    if(referer == 'Ngfw'){
        var menu_url = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/ngfw-cdss-nav-renderer.php';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/ngfwcdsssearch";
    }
    httpGet(menu_url,'menu_html');
    document.getElementById('main-nav-menu-cont').removeAttribute("style");
}
function addStyle(styles) {            
    /* Create style document */
    var css = document.createElement('style');
    css.type = 'text/css';

    if (css.styleSheet) 
        css.styleSheet.cssText = styles;
    else 
        css.appendChild(document.createTextNode(styles));

    /* Append style to the tag name */
    document.getElementsByTagName("head")[0].appendChild(css);
}
function httpGet(theUrl,req_type) {
    if (window.XMLHttpRequest) { // code for IE7+, Firefox, Chrome, Opera, Safari
        xmlhttp=new XMLHttpRequest();
    } else {// code for IE6, IE5
        xmlhttp=new ActiveXObject("Microsoft.XMLHTTP");
    }
    xmlhttp.onreadystatechange=function()
    {
        if (xmlhttp.readyState==4 && xmlhttp.status==200)
        {
            if(req_type == 'menu_html'){
            var nav_text = xmlhttp.responseText.replaceAll('https://static.cloud.coveo.com/searchui/v2.9159/js/CoveoJsSearch.Lazy.min.js', '');
            nav_text = nav_text.replaceAll('src="/', 'src="'+maindomain_lang+'/');
            nav_text = nav_text.replaceAll("'/content", "'"+maindomain_lang+"/content");
                        
            document.getElementById("PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC").innerHTML = nav_text.replaceAll('href="/', 'href="'+maindomain_lang+'/');

            var lozad_back = document.getElementsByClassName('lozad-background');
            Array.prototype.forEach.call(lozad_back, function(el) {
            // Do stuff here
            var el_back_img_path = el.getAttribute('data-background-image');
            var first_pos = el_back_img_path.indexOf("'");
            var last_pos = el_back_img_path.indexOf("'",first_pos+1);
            el_back_img_path = el_back_img_path.substring(first_pos+1,last_pos);
            el.setAttribute("data-background-image",main_site_url+el_back_img_path);
            });
            }
            if(req_type == 'head_inline_css'){
            addStyle(xmlhttp.responseText);
            }
        }
    }
    xmlhttp.open("GET", theUrl, true );
    xmlhttp.send();    
}    
    
if(referer == 'Prisma' || referer == 'Cortex' || referer == 'Sase' || referer == 'Unit' || referer == 'Ngfw'){
    const article = document.querySelector('#PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC');
    if(referer == 'Prisma'){
        article.dataset.type = 'prisma';
        $('#PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC').removeClass('default').addClass('defaultRedesigned');
    }
    else if(referer == 'Cortex'){
        article.dataset.type = 'cortex';
    }
    else if(referer == 'Sase'){
        article.dataset.type = 'sase';
    }
    else if(referer == 'Unit'){
        article.dataset.type = 'unit';
    }
    else if(referer == 'Ngfw'){
        article.dataset.type = 'ngfw';
    }
    //set class to default
    if(referer == 'Unit' || referer == 'Ngfw'){
        $('#PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC').removeClass('default').addClass('defaultRedesigned');
    }
    callMainSitePrismaNavHTML();        
}
</script>
<!--  End: Scripts Migrated From Unit42-v5 -->



<main class="main">
    <section class="section section--article">
        <div class="pa article-banner" style="background-image:url('https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/06_Ransomware_Category_1920x900.jpg')">
          <div class="l-container">

              <div class="ab-lc__wrapper">
                <span class="ab-title__pre">Related Products</span><div class="ab__link-cards"><a class="l-linkcard is-blue" role="link" title="Advanced WildFire" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="bianlian-ransomware-group-threat-assessment:hero:Advanced WildFire"><img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/strata_RGB_logo_Icon_Color.png" alt="Advanced WildFire icon">Advanced WildFire</a><a class="l-linkcard is-blue" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/product-category/cloud-delivered-security-services/" style="--card-color: #ffcb06" role="link" title="Cloud-Delivered Security Services" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="bianlian-ransomware-group-threat-assessment:hero:Cloud-Delivered Security Services"><img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/strata_RGB_logo_Icon_Color.png" alt="Cloud-Delivered Security Services icon">Cloud-Delivered Security Services</a><a class="l-linkcard is-blue" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/product-category/cortex-xdr/" style="--card-color: #00cc66" role="link" title="Cortex XDR" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="bianlian-ransomware-group-threat-assessment:hero:Cortex XDR"><img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/cortex_RGB_logo_Icon_Color.png" alt="Cortex XDR icon">Cortex XDR</a><a class="l-linkcard is-blue" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/product-category/next-generation-firewall/" style="--card-color: #ffcb06" role="link" title="Next-Generation Firewall" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="bianlian-ransomware-group-threat-assessment:hero:Next-Generation Firewall"><img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/strata_RGB_logo_Icon_Color.png" alt="Next-Generation Firewall icon">Next-Generation Firewall</a></div>              </div>
            </div>
          </div>
          <div class="ab__footer">
            <div class="l-container">
              <div class="ab__footer-wrapper">
                <ul class="ab__features" role="list">
                  <li role="listitem">
				 <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-profile-grey.svg" alt="Profile Icon">
					 <div class="ab__text"><span>By:</span><ul class="ab__tags"><li><a data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="bianlian-ransomware-group-threat-assessment:hero:Daniel Frank" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/author/daniel-frank/">Daniel Frank</a></li></ul></div></li>                  <li role="listitem">
			<img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-calendar-grey.svg" alt="Published Icon">
			<div class="ab__text"><span>Published:</span>23 January, 2024 at 3:00 AM PST</div></li>					<li role="listitem"><img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-category.svg" alt="Tags Icon"><div class="ab__text"><span>Categories:</span><ul class="ab__tags"><li><a data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="bianlian-ransomware-group-threat-assessment:hero:Cybercrime" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/cybercrime/">Cybercrime</a></li><li><a data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="bianlian-ransomware-group-threat-assessment:hero:High Profile Threats" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/top-cyberthreats/">High Profile Threats</a></li><li><a data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="bianlian-ransomware-group-threat-assessment:hero:Ransomware" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/ransomware/">Ransomware</a></li></ul></div>
		</li>                  <li role="listitem"><img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-tags-grey.svg" alt="Tags Icon"><div class="ab__text"><span>Tags:</span><ul class="ab__tags"><li><a data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="bianlian-ransomware-group-threat-assessment:hero:BianLian" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/bianlian/">BianLian</a></li><li><a data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="bianlian-ransomware-group-threat-assessment:hero:Bitter Scorpius" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/bitter-scorpius/">Bitter Scorpius</a></li><li><a data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="bianlian-ransomware-group-threat-assessment:hero:Makop" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/makop/">Makop</a></li></ul></div>
		</li>                </ul>
                <div class="ab__options">
                  <ul role="list">
                                        <li role="listitem"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/bianlian-ransomware-group-threat-assessment/?pdf=download&#038;lg=en&#038;_wpnonce=dcff69efdc" role="link" target="_blank"  title="Click here to download" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="bianlian-ransomware-group-threat-assessment:hero:pdfdownload"> <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-download.svg" alt="Download Icon"></a></li>
                    <li role="listitem"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/bianlian-ransomware-group-threat-assessment/?pdf=print&#038;lg=en&#038;_wpnonce=dcff69efdc" target="_blank" role="link" title="Click here to print" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="bianlian-ransomware-group-threat-assessment:hero:pdfprint"> <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-print.svg" alt="Print Icon"></a></li>
                  </ul>
                  
	<div class="ab__share" id="shareDropdown" role="button" aria-expanded="false">

            </div>
          </div>
        </div>
      </section> 
    <section class="section blog-contents"> 
      <div class="pa blog-editor">
        <div class="l-container">
          <div class="be__wrapper">
            <div class="be__contents">
              <div class="be__contents-wrapper">
                <p class="wpml-ls-statics-post_translations wpml-ls">This post is also available in: 
    <span class="wpml-ls-slot-post_translations wpml-ls-item wpml-ls-item-ja wpml-ls-first-item wpml-ls-last-item wpml-ls-item-legacy-post-translations"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.jp/bianlian-ransomware-group-threat-assessment/" class="wpml-ls-link"><span class="wpml-ls-native" lang="ja">日本語</span><span class="wpml-ls-display"><span class="wpml-ls-bracket"> (</span>Japanese<span class="wpml-ls-bracket">)</span></span></a></span></p><h2><a id="post-132125-_1ckpps1kzm65"></a>Executive Summary</h2>
<p>Unit 42 researchers have been tracking the BianLian ransomware group, which has been in the top 10 of the most active groups based on leak site data we’ve gathered. From that leak site data, we’ve primarily observed activity affecting the healthcare and manufacturing sectors and industries, and impacting organizations mainly in the United States (US) and Europe (EU).</p>
<p>We also observed that the BianLian group shares a small, customized tool in common with the Makop ransomware group. This shared tool indicates a possible connection between the two groups, which we will explore further.</p>
<p>BianLian has also recently moved from a double extortion scheme to one of extortion without encryption. Rather than encrypting their victims’ assets before stealing data and threatening to publish it if they do not pay the ransom, they’re now moving straight to stealing data to motivate victims to pay.</p>
<p>The Unit 42 Incident Response team has responded to several BianLian ransomware incidents since September 2022.</p>
<p>Palo Alto Networks customers are better protected against ransomware used by the BianLian ransomware group through <a href="https://docs-cortex.paloaltonetworks.com/p/XDR" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Cortex XDR</a>, as well as by <a href="https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/cdss" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Cloud-Delivered Security Services</a> for the <a href="https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/ngfw" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Next-Generation Firewall</a> such as <a href="https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/wildfire" target="_blank" rel="noopener">WildFire</a> and <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/network-security/advanced-url-filtering" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Advanced URL Filtering</a>.</p>
<p>In particular, the Cortex XDR anti-ransomware module included out-of-the-box protections that prevented adverse behavior from the ransomware samples we tested without the need for specific detection logic or signatures.</p>
<p>The <a href="https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/prisma/prisma-cloud" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Prisma Cloud</a> Defender should be deployed on cloud-based Windows virtual machines to ensure they are protected. <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/cortex/cortex-xpanse" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Cortex Xpanse</a> is able to provide visibility that can prove valuable for proactive protection.</p>
<p>The <a href="https://start.paloaltonetworks.com/contact-unit42.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Unit 42 Incident Response team</a> can also be engaged to help with a compromise or to provide a proactive assessment to lower your risk.</p>
<table style="width: 100%;">
<thead>
<tr>
<td style="width: 35%;"><b>Related Unit 42 Topics</b></td>
<td style="width: 100%;"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/ransomware/" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><b>Ransomware</b></a>, <strong><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/cybercrime/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Cybercrime</a></strong></td>
</tr>
</thead>
</table>
<h2>BianLian Threat Overview</h2>
<p>The BianLian group has been extremely active ever since it <a href="https://redacted.com/blog/bianlian-ransomware-gang-gives-it-a-go/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">emerged in 2022</a>, with new organizations compromised by the group being reported on their leak site almost on a weekly basis. Figure 1 below details their activity throughout 2023, as illustrated by their leak site data.</p>
<figure id="attachment_132128" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-132128" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-132128" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/01/chart-2.png" alt="Image 1 is a graph of BianLian group activity from January to December 2023. The sharpest spike occurs in May and then falls with the lowest point in August. It then starts to climb upward again. " width="900" height="728" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-132128" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 1. Activity of the BianLian group throughout 2023.</figcaption></figure>
<p>This group impacts mainly the healthcare, manufacturing, professional and legal services sectors. Their attacks have primarily taken place in North America, but they were also seen in the EU and India.</p>
<p><a href="https://www.cisa.gov/news-events/cybersecurity-advisories/aa23-136a" target="_blank" rel="noopener">BianLian</a> shares a small custom .NET tool with the <a href="https://medium.com/@lcam/makop-the-toolkit-of-a-criminal-gang-53cd44563c11" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Makop</a> ransomware group, which indicates a possible connection between the two groups.</p>
<p>BianLian has moved from a double extortion scheme of encrypting their victims’ assets, stealing data, and threatening to publish it if they do not pay the ransom to a main focus of <a href="https://redacted.com/blog/bianlian-ransomware-gang-continues-to-evolve/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">extortion</a> without encryption.</p>
<p>The group’s leak site indicates that BianLian might be expanding by hiring new developers and affiliates, as noted in the “Work with us” section from the group's homepage shown below in Figure 2.</p>
<p><figure id="attachment_132130" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-132130" style="width: 800px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-132130" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/01/word-image-132125-2.png" alt="Image 2 is a screenshot of the BianLian leak site homepage as of December 2023. BianLian. Categories are Home, Companies, Tags, Contacts. Work with us: targets’ providers, software engineers, pentesters, journalists. Tox: [redacted]. Email: [redacted onion email]. Most of the following text is also redacted. " width="800" height="583" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-132130" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 2. The BianLian leak site homepage, late December 2023.</figcaption></figure>The BianLian group regularly updates the list of compromised targets on their leak site. Figure 3 details the most affected countries. While BianLian has impacted organizations all over the world, the US is clearly the most affected country as of 2023.</p>
<figure id="attachment_132132" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-132132" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-132132" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/01/chart-3.png" alt="Image 3 is a heat map of countries impacted by BianLian over 2023. The highest affected country is North America followed by parts of the EU and India. " width="900" height="560" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-132132" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 3. A map showing the countries impacted by BianLian in 2023.</figcaption></figure>
<p>As detailed in Figure 4 below, healthcare is the sector most affected by the BianLian group, with manufacturing a close second. In January 2023, the group claimed to have <a href="https://thecyberexpress.com/bianlian-ransomware-st-rose-hospital-as-victim/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">exfiltrated 1.7 TB of data</a>, including personal data of patients and employees, from a California-based hospital. Attacks on healthcare organizations are especially concerning because they disrupt hospitals’ day-to-day operations and potentially endanger patients' lives.</p>
<figure id="attachment_132134" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-132134" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-132134" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/01/chart-4.png" alt="Image 4 is a column graph of all of the industries attacked by BianLian in 2023. The most-attacked sectors are healthcare, manufacturing and professional and legal services. " width="900" height="574" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-132134" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 4. The distribution of the sectors that BianLian attacked in 2023.</figcaption></figure>
<h2><a id="post-132125-_6fnsr8i5a39j"></a>Possible Connection to Makop Ransomware</h2>
<p>During our analysis, we noticed a <a href="https://www.virustotal.com/gui/file/40126ae71b857dd22db39611c25d3d5dd0e60316b72830e930fba9baf23973ce" target="_blank" rel="noopener">small .NET custom executable</a> was shared between the <a href="https://www.cisa.gov/news-events/cybersecurity-advisories/aa23-136a" target="_blank" rel="noopener">BianLian</a> and <a href="https://medium.com/@lcam/makop-the-toolkit-of-a-criminal-gang-53cd44563c11" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Makop</a> ransomware groups. Both groups also used the same hash of the publicly available Advanced Port Scanner tool.</p>
<p>This .NET tool is responsible for retrieving file enumeration, registry and clipboard data. This tool contains some words in the Russian language, such as the numbers one to four. The use of such a tool indicates that the two groups might have shared a tool set or used the services of the same developers in the past.</p>
<p>A possible – yet not confirmed – explanation for this overlap is that BianLian could be sharing a codebase with the Makop group, or using the services of the same third-party developers. This phenomenon is well-known and documented among certain underground cybercrime groups.</p>
<p>Another noteworthy fact is that the Makop ransomware was documented <a href="https://www.lifars.com/knowledge-center/makop-ransomware/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">excluding certain file extensions</a> when encrypting an infected endpoint, including known extensions that are used by other ransomware strains. This is yet another indicator of possible existing relationships among these threat actors, or at least a “not stepping on someone’s toes” approach when it involves other ransomware groups.</p>
<h2><a id="post-132125-_ft0qs2ot67hn"></a>Technical Analysis</h2>
<h3><a id="post-132125-_gfhc1tm81o4b"></a>Attack Lifecycle</h3>
<p>We have mapped the attack stages that are common with the BianLian group to the MITRE ATT&amp;CK framework, which is summarized below.</p>
<h4><a id="post-132125-_t3pinwo6m3oa"></a>Initial Access</h4>
<p>To infiltrate corporate networks, BianLian operators often perform the following activities:</p>
<ul>
<li>Use stolen Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP) credentials</li>
<li>Exploit the ProxyShell vulnerability</li>
<li>Target virtual private network (VPN) providers</li>
<li>Use other <a href="https://redacted.com/blog/bianlian-ransomware-gang-gives-it-a-go/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">previously reported</a> techniques such as deploying web shells</li>
</ul>
<p>During the last year, BianLian’s methods of infiltration and lateral movement <a href="https://redacted.com/blog/bianlian-ransomware-gang-continues-to-evolve/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">did not change much</a>. Nevertheless, we were able to retrieve interesting forensic data from our telemetry that provides additional behavioral indicators of compromise (IoCs).</p>
<p>After successfully infiltrating an organization’s network, our telemetry indicates the BianLian group uses various public tools to move laterally, dump credentials and remotely execute a backdoor payload.</p>
<h4><a id="post-132125-_qo0ldbx83ojh"></a>Credential Dumping</h4>
<p>In our telemetry, we have witnessed dumping of the Security Accounts Manager (SAM) registry hive into a file at <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">%windir%\Temp</span>. This is a <a href="https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1003/002/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">common technique</a> used by attackers.</p>
<p>The SAM stores hashed passwords from accounts used on the attacked machine, and it can be recovered when processing <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">SYSTEM</span> privileges. The corresponding Cortex XDR alert is shown in Figure 5.</p>
<figure id="attachment_132136" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-132136" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-132136" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/01/word-image-132125-5.png" alt="Image 5 is a screenshot of an alert in Cortex XDR. The categories are Severity, which is high, the alert source, action, category, alert name and description. " width="900" height="84" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-132136" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 5. SAM dumping alert in Cortex XDR.</figcaption></figure>
<h4><a id="post-132125-_co48iq406wq8"></a>Persistence</h4>
<p>During the analysis of our telemetry, we saw the attackers drop the BianLian backdoor DLL component under the following path:</p>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">c:\\programdata\\vmware\\[filename].dll.</span></li>
</ul>
<p>To execute the backdoor, they used the <a href="https://github.com/fortra/impacket" target="_blank" rel="noopener">impacket</a> tool to create the following scheduled task:</p><!-- Crayon Syntax Highlighter v_2.7.2_beta -->

		<div id="crayon-6719b44cd03e7743887779" class="crayon-syntax crayon-theme-classic crayon-font-monaco crayon-os-pc print-yes notranslate" data-settings=" minimize scroll-mouseover wrap" style=" margin-top: 12px; margin-bottom: 12px; font-size: 12px !important; line-height: 15px !important;">
		
			<div class="crayon-toolbar" data-settings=" mouseover overlay hide delay" style="font-size: 12px !important;height: 18px !important; line-height: 18px !important;"><span class="crayon-title"></span>
			<div class="crayon-tools" style="font-size: 12px !important;height: 18px !important; line-height: 18px !important;"><div class="crayon-button crayon-nums-button" title="Toggle Line Numbers"><div class="crayon-button-icon"></div></div><div class="crayon-button crayon-plain-button" title="Toggle Plain Code"><div class="crayon-button-icon"></div></div><div class="crayon-button crayon-wrap-button" title="Toggle Line Wrap"><div class="crayon-button-icon"></div></div><div class="crayon-button crayon-expand-button" title="Expand Code"><div class="crayon-button-icon"></div></div><div class="crayon-button crayon-copy-button" title="Copy"><div class="crayon-button-icon"></div></div><div class="crayon-button crayon-popup-button" title="Open Code In New Window"><div class="crayon-button-icon"></div></div></div></div>
			<div class="crayon-info" style="min-height: 16.8px !important; line-height: 16.8px !important;"></div>
			<div class="crayon-plain-wrap"><textarea  class="crayon-plain print-no" data-settings="dblclick" readonly style="-moz-tab-size:4; -o-tab-size:4; -webkit-tab-size:4; tab-size:4; font-size: 12px !important; line-height: 15px !important;">
cmd.exe /C rundll32.exe
c:\\programdata\\vmware\\[filename].dll,Entry &gt;
C:\\Windows\\Temp\\[filename].tmp 2&gt;&amp;1.</textarea></div>
			<div class="crayon-main" style="">
				<table class="crayon-table">
					<tr class="crayon-row">
				<td class="crayon-nums " data-settings="show">
					<div class="crayon-nums-content" style="font-size: 12px !important; line-height: 15px !important;"><div class="crayon-num" data-line="crayon-6719b44cd03e7743887779-1">1</div><div class="crayon-num crayon-striped-num" data-line="crayon-6719b44cd03e7743887779-2">2</div><div class="crayon-num" data-line="crayon-6719b44cd03e7743887779-3">3</div></div>
				</td>
						<td class="crayon-code"><div class="crayon-pre" style="font-size: 12px !important; line-height: 15px !important; -moz-tab-size:4; -o-tab-size:4; -webkit-tab-size:4; tab-size:4;"><div class="crayon-line" id="crayon-6719b44cd03e7743887779-1"><span class="crayon-i">cmd</span><span class="crayon-sy">.</span><span class="crayon-i">exe</span><span class="crayon-h"> </span>/<span class="crayon-i">C</span><span class="crayon-h"> </span><span class="crayon-i">rundll32</span><span class="crayon-sy">.</span><span class="crayon-i">exe</span></div><div class="crayon-line crayon-striped-line" id="crayon-6719b44cd03e7743887779-2"><span class="crayon-i">c</span><span class="crayon-sy">:</span><span class="crayon-sy">\</span><span class="crayon-sy">\</span><span class="crayon-i">programdata</span><span class="crayon-sy">\</span><span class="crayon-sy">\</span><span class="crayon-i">vmware</span><span class="crayon-sy">\</span><span class="crayon-sy">\</span><span class="crayon-sy">[</span><span class="crayon-i">filename</span><span class="crayon-sy">]</span><span class="crayon-sy">.</span><span class="crayon-i">dll</span><span class="crayon-sy">,</span><span class="crayon-i">Entry</span><span class="crayon-h"> </span><span class="crayon-h">&gt;</span></div><div class="crayon-line" id="crayon-6719b44cd03e7743887779-3"><span class="crayon-i">C</span><span class="crayon-sy">:</span><span class="crayon-sy">\</span><span class="crayon-sy">\</span><span class="crayon-i">Windows</span><span class="crayon-sy">\</span><span class="crayon-sy">\</span><span class="crayon-i">Temp</span><span class="crayon-sy">\</span><span class="crayon-sy">\</span><span class="crayon-sy">[</span><span class="crayon-i">filename</span><span class="crayon-sy">]</span><span class="crayon-sy">.</span><span class="crayon-i">tmp</span><span class="crayon-h"> </span><span class="crayon-cn">2</span><span class="crayon-h">&gt;</span><span class="crayon-h">&amp;1</span><span class="crayon-sy">.</span></div></div></td>
					</tr>
				</table>
			</div>
		</div>
<!-- [Format Time: 0.0002 seconds] -->
<p>The creation of the task was detected by Cortex XDR, and the corresponding alert is shown in Figure 6 below.</p>
<figure id="attachment_132138" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-132138" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-132138" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/01/word-image-132125-6.png" alt="Image 6 is a screenshot of an alert in Cortex XDR. The categories are Severity, which is high, the alert source, action, category, alert name and description. " width="900" height="75" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-132138" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 6. The impacket task creation alert in Cortex XDR.</figcaption></figure>
<p>This task’s role is to periodically execute the backdoor DLL with its export function named <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Entry</span>, using <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">rundll32</span>. The execution of the backdoor DLL was detected and prevented by Cortex XDR. The alert and prevention pop-up are shown in Figures 7 and 8, respectively.</p>
<figure id="attachment_132140" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-132140" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-132140" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/01/word-image-132125-7.png" alt="Image 7 is a screenshot of an alert in Cortex XDR. The categories are Severity, which is medium, the alert source, action, category, alert name and description. " width="900" height="93" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-132140" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 7. The backdoor execution detection by Cortex XDR in detect mode.</figcaption></figure>
<figure id="attachment_132142" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-132142" style="width: 500px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-132142" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/01/word-image-132125-8.png" alt="Image 8 is a screenshot of the Cortex XDR Prevention Alert window. Cortex XDR has blocked a malicious activity! Application name: Windows host process. Application publisher: Microsoft Corporation. File origin: Hard drive on this computer." width="500" height="398" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-132142" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 8. The backdoor execution prevention by Cortex XDR in prevent mode.</figcaption></figure>
<p>The backdoors themselves have different names and paths in each incident, thus making it difficult to implement naming-based behavioral detection.</p>
<h4><a id="post-132125-_r11czpodbg17"></a>Reconnaissance</h4>
<p>To get a better picture of an already infected network’s open ports that attackers can later use for lateral movement, the tool <a href="https://www.virustotal.com/gui/file/d0c1662ce239e4d288048c0e3324ec52962f6ddda77da0cb7af9c1d9c2f1e2eb" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Advanced Port Scanner</a> by Famatech was used from the following path:</p>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">C:\\Users\\%username%\\AppData\\Local\\Temp\\31\\Advanced_Port_Scanner_2.5.3869.exe</span></li>
</ul>
<p>This is the same Advanced Port Scanner file that Makop ransomware was <a href="https://medium.com/@lcam/makop-the-toolkit-of-a-criminal-gang-53cd44563c11" target="_blank" rel="noopener">previously documented</a> using. The alerts raised by its execution are shown in Figure 9.</p>
<figure id="attachment_132144" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-132144" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-132144" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/01/word-image-132125-9.png" alt="Image 9 is a screenshot of an alert in Cortex XDR. The categories are Severity, which is Informational (two instances) and medium (one instance), the alert source, action, category, and alert name." width="900" height="163" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-132144" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 9. Alerts raised by the execution of Advanced Port Scanner.</figcaption></figure>
<h4><a id="post-132125-_jo21nsn2qml"></a>Encryptor and Backdoor</h4>
<p>Since the beginning of their activity, BianLian used two main components for their final payloads: an encryptor and a <a href="https://redacted.com/blog/bianlian-ransomware-gang-gives-it-a-go/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">backdoor</a>. Figure 10 below shows the encryptor’s ransom note.</p>
<p><figure id="attachment_132146" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-132146" style="width: 700px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-132146" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/01/word-image-132125-10.png" alt="Image 10 is a screenshot of a BianLian ransomware note. Title: Look at this instruction.txt. Your network systems were attacked and encrypted. Contact us in order to restore your date. Don’t make any changes in your file structure: touch no files, don’t try to recover by yourself, that may lead to its complete loss. To contact us you have to download “tox” messenger. Add user with the following ID to get your instructions [redacted]. Alternative way [redacted email]. Your ID: [redacted]. You should know that we have been downloading data rom your network for a significant time before the attack: financial, client, business, post, technical and personal files. In 10 days it will be posted at our site. [redacted] with links. Send to your clients, partners, competitors and news agencies, that will lead to a negative impact on your company: potential financial, business and reputational loses. " width="700" height="469" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-132146" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 10. Example of a ransom note generated by a BianLian encryptor first seen in April 2023.</figcaption></figure>In early 2023, Avast released a <a href="https://decoded.avast.io/threatresearch/decrypted-bianlian-ransomware/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">decryptor for BianLian's encryptor</a>, which ultimately caused the group to cease most of its encryption activity. The threat actors then shifted their operation into a steal-and-extort scheme, mainly relying on their custom backdoor.</p>
<p><a href="https://redacted.com/blog/bianlian-ransomware-gang-gives-it-a-go/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">BianLian's backdoor</a>, similar to the encryptor, is written in Go. Its core functionality is more of a loader than a classic backdoor, with its main functionality being downloading and executing additional payloads. The backdoor contains a hard-coded C2 IP address and port to communicate with.</p>
<p>As shown in Figures 11 and 12, Cortex XDR successfully detected the execution of the encryptor, using its anti-ransomware module and other behavioral and static detection signatures.</p>
<figure id="attachment_132148" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-132148" style="width: 500px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-132148" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/01/word-image-132125-11.png" alt="Image 11 is a screenshot of an alert in Cortex XDR. " width="500" height="301" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-132148" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 11. BianLian encryptor detection by Cortex XDR in detect mode.</figcaption></figure>
<figure id="attachment_132150" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-132150" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-132150" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/01/word-image-132125-12.png" alt="Image 12 is a screenshot of alerts in Cortex XDR. They were initiated by bianlian_encryptor.exe. " width="900" height="210" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-132150" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 12. Alerts raised by Cortex XDR detecting the BianLian encryptor in detect mode.</figcaption></figure>
<p>As shown in Figure 13, when operating in prevent mode, the BianLian encryptor is prevented by Cortex XDR.</p>
<figure id="attachment_132152" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-132152" style="width: 400px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-132152" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/01/word-image-132125-13.png" alt="Image 13 is a screenshot of the Cortex XDR Prevention Alert window. Cortex XDR has blocked a malicious activity! Application name: bianlian_encrypotr.exe. Application publisher: Unknown" width="400" height="220" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-132152" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 13. The BianLian encryptor is prevented by Cortex XDR in prevent mode.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Figures 14 and 15 below demonstrate how Cortex XDR also detected the BianLian custom backdoor in detect mode and prevented it in prevent mode.</p>
<figure id="attachment_132154" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-132154" style="width: 400px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-132154" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/01/word-image-132125-14.jpeg" alt="Image 14 is a screenshot of an alert in Cortex XDR. " width="400" height="168" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-132154" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 14. Cortex XDR detecting the BianLian backdoor in detect mode.</figcaption></figure>
<figure id="attachment_132156" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-132156" style="width: 400px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-132156" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/01/word-image-132125-15.png" alt="Image 15 is a screenshot of the Cortex XDR Prevention Alert window. Cortex XDR has blocked a malicious activity! Application name: bianlian_encrypotr.exe. Application publisher: Unknown. " width="400" height="220" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-132156" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 15. The BianLian backdoor is prevented by Cortex XDR in prevent mode.</figcaption></figure>
<h2><a id="post-132125-_9fmcpdfg1wdt"></a>Conclusion</h2>
<p>Following its discovery in 2022, the BianLian group has been one of the most active and prevalent extortion groups in the cyberthreat landscape. Out of the leak site data tracked by Unit 42 between January and mid-December of 2023, BianLian was in the top 10 of the most active groups. There is a growing list of alleged victims that they update on their leak site.</p>
<p>Maintaining their tactics, techniques and procedures (TTPs) of infiltrating corporate networks, the BianLian group has shown adaptiveness to the ransomware market demands. They have shifted from double-extortion into being focused solely on extortion efforts, pressuring their victims into paying the ransom without encrypting their files. A possible connection to the Makop ransomware group was also found, due to their mutual use of a custom tool.</p>
<h2><a id="post-132125-_ka1fluf0dtdv"></a>Protections and Mitigations</h2>
<p><a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/blog/security-operations/beating-alert-fatigue-with-cortex-xdr-smartscore-technology/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">SmartScore</a>, a unique ML-driven scoring engine that translates security investigation methods and their associated data into a hybrid scoring system, scored an incident involving BianLian backdoor at 91 out of 100, as shown in Figure 16. This type of scoring helps analysts determine which incidents are more urgent and provides context about the reason for the assessment, assisting with prioritization.</p>
<figure id="attachment_132158" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-132158" style="width: 565px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-132158" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/01/word-image-132125-16.png" alt="Image 16 is a screenshot of SmartScore information scored at 91. It includes why the score was set and also insights. " width="565" height="436" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-132158" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 16. SmartScore information about a BianLian backdoor incident.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Palo Alto Networks customers are better protected from the BianLian encryptor and backdoor components.</p>
<p>The Cortex XDR and XSIAM platforms detect and prevent the execution flow described in the screenshots included in the previous section.</p>
<p>The Cortex XDR agent included out of the box protections that prevented adverse behavior from the samples we tested from this group, without the need for specific detection logic or signatures.</p>
<p><a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/cortex/cortex-xdr?_gl=1*13pmp8e*_ga*NzQyNjM2NzkuMTY2NjY3OTczNw..*_ga_KS2MELEEFC*MTY2OTczNjA2MS4zMS4wLjE2Njk3MzYwNjEuNjAuMC4w" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Cortex XDR</a> and XSIAM detect user- and credential-based threats by analyzing user activity from multiple data sources including the following:</p>
<ul>
<li>Endpoints</li>
<li>Network firewalls</li>
<li>Active Directory</li>
<li>Identity and access management solutions</li>
<li>Cloud workloads</li>
</ul>
<p>Cortex XDR and XSIAM build behavioral profiles of user activity over time with machine learning. By comparing new activity to past activity, peer activity and the expected behavior of the entity, Cortex XDR and XSIAM detect anomalous activity indicative of credential-based attacks.</p>
<p>They also offer the following protections related to the attacks discussed in this post:</p>
<ul>
<li>Prevent the execution of known malicious malware</li>
<li>Prevent execution of unknown malware using <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/products/secure-the-network/subscriptions/threat-prevention?_gl=1*13pmp8e*_ga*NzQyNjM2NzkuMTY2NjY3OTczNw..*_ga_KS2MELEEFC*MTY2OTczNjA2MS4zMS4wLjE2Njk3MzYwNjEuNjAuMC4w" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Behavioral Threat Protection and</a> machine learning based on the Local Analysis module</li>
<li>Protect against credential-gathering tools and techniques using the Credential Gathering Protection, available from Cortex XDR 3.4</li>
<li>Protect against exploitation of different vulnerabilities including ProxyShell using the Anti-Exploitation modules as well as Behavioral Threat Protection</li>
</ul>
<p>Cortex XDR Pro detects post-exploitation activity, including credential-based attacks, with <a href="https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/cortex/cortex-xdr/cortex-xdr-analytics-alert-reference/cortex-xdr-analytics-alert-reference/analytics-alerts-by-required-data-source" target="_blank" rel="noopener">behavioral analytics</a>.</p>
<p>The <a href="https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/prisma/prisma-cloud" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Prisma Cloud</a> Defender as well as Cortex XDR for cloud agents should be deployed on cloud-based Windows virtual machines to ensure they are protected from these known malicious binaries. <a href="https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/wildfire" target="_blank" rel="noopener">WildFire</a> signatures can be used by both Palo Alto Networks cloud services to ensure cloud-based Windows virtual machine runtime operations are being analyzed and those resources are protected.</p>
<p><a href="https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/cdss" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Cloud-Delivered Security Services</a> for the <a href="https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/ngfw" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Next-Generation Firewall</a> such as <a href="https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/wildfire" target="_blank" rel="noopener">WildFire</a> and <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/network-security/advanced-url-filtering" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Advanced URL Filtering</a> include protections based on the IoCs shared in this article.</p>
<p><a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/cortex/cortex-xpanse">Cortex Xpanse</a> is also able to detect exposed RDP and many other remote access interfaces which are often brute forced or exploited with compromised credentials. This visibility can prove valuable through proactive prevention.</p>
<figure id="attachment_132160" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-132160" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-132160" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/01/word-image-132125-17.png" alt="Image 17 is a screenshot of Cortex Xpanse Attack Surface rules. It includes the following categories: Status. Severity, Rule Name, Description, Remediation Guidance and more. " width="900" height="302" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-132160" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 17. A subset of the exposed remote access interface types that Cortex Xpanse can detect.</figcaption></figure>
<p>If you think you might have been impacted or have an urgent matter, get in touch with the <a href="https://start.paloaltonetworks.com/contact-unit42.html?_gl=1*13pmp8e*_ga*NzQyNjM2NzkuMTY2NjY3OTczNw..*_ga_KS2MELEEFC*MTY2OTczNjA2MS4zMS4wLjE2Njk3MzYwNjEuNjAuMC4w" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Unit 42 Incident Response team</a> or call:</p>
<ul>
<li>North America Toll-Free: 866.486.4842 (866.4.UNIT42)</li>
<li>EMEA: +31.20.299.3130</li>
<li>APAC: +65.6983.8730</li>
<li>Japan: +81.50.1790.0200</li>
</ul>
<p>Palo Alto Networks has shared these findings with our fellow Cyber Threat Alliance (CTA) members. CTA members use this intelligence to rapidly deploy protections to their customers and to systematically disrupt malicious cyber actors. Learn more about the <a href="https://www.cyberthreatalliance.org" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Cyber Threat Alliance</a>.</p>
<h2><a id="post-132125-_u6j4jrmuhgk8"></a>Indicators of Compromise</h2>
<h3><a id="post-132125-_49bv03c0jxg8"></a>Examples of the BianLian Encryptor</h3>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">af46356eb70f0fbb0799f8a8d5c0f7513d2f6ade4f16d4869f2690029b511d4f</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">1fd42d07b4be99e0e503c0ed5af2274312be1b03e01b54a6d89c0eef04257d6e</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">3a2f6e614ff030804aa18cb03fcc3bc357f6226786efb4a734cbe2a3a1984b6f</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">46d340eaf6b78207e24b6011422f1a5b4a566e493d72365c6a1cace11c36b28b</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">1fd07b8d1728e416f897bef4f1471126f9b18ef108eb952f4b75050da22e8e43</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">eaf5e26c5e73f3db82cd07ea45e4d244ccb3ec3397ab5263a1a74add7bbcb6e2</span></li>
</ul>
<h3><a id="post-132125-_jiehdrprrnuc"></a>Examples of the BianLian Backdoor</h3>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">c775e6d87a3bcc5e94cd055fee859bdb6350af033114fe8588d2d4d4f6d2a3ae</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">c57ca631b069745027d0b4f4d717821ca9bd095e28de2eafe4723eeaf4b062cf</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">c592194cea0acf3d3e181d2ba3108f0f86d74bcd8e49457981423f5f902d054b</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">df51b7b031ecc7c7fa899e17cce98b005576a20a199be670569d5e408d21048c</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">2ed448721f4e92c7970972f029290ee6269689c840a922982ac2f39c9a6a838f</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">264af7e7aa17422eb4299df640c1aa199b4778509697b6b296efa5ae7e957b40</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">73d095abf2f31358c8b1fb0d5a0dc9807e88d44282c896b5033c1b270d44111f</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">8b65c9437445e9bcb8164d8557ecb9e3585c8bebf37099a3ec1437884efbdd24</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">4ca84be5b6ab91694a0f81350cefe8379efcad692872a383671ce4209295edc7</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">93fb7f0c2cf10fb5885e03c737ee8508816c1102e9e3d358160b78e91fa1ebdb</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">afb7f11da27439a2e223e6b651f96eb16a7e35b34918e501886d25439015bf78</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">53095e2ad802072e97dbb8a7ccea03a36d1536fce921c80a7a2f160c83366999</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">16cbfd155fb44c6fd0f9375376f62a90ac09f8b7689c1afb5b9b4d3e76e28bdf</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">60b1394f3afee27701e2008f46d766ef466caa7711c45ddfd443a71efc39a407</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">ba3c4bc99b67038b42b75a206d7ef04f6d8abaf87a76c373d4dec85e73859ce2</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">e7e097723d00f58eab785baf30365c1495e99aa6ead6fe1b86109558838d294e</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">96e02ea8b1c508f1ee3c1535547f9b89396f557011e61478644ae5876cdaaca5</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">ac1d42360c45e0e908d07e784ceb15faf8987e4ba1744d56313de6524d2687f7</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">1cba58f73221b5bb7930bfeab0106ae5415e70f49a595727022dcf6fda1126e9</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">487f0d748a13570a46b20b6687eb7b7fc70a1a55e676fb5ff2599096a1ca888c</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">f84edc07b23423f2c2cad47c0600133cab3cf2bd6072ad45649d6faf3b70ec30</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">93953eef3fe8405d563560dc332135bfe5874ddeb373d714862f72ee62bef518</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">f3f3c692f728b9c8fd2e1c090b60223ac6c6e88bf186c98ed9842408b78b9f3c</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">f6669de3baa1bca649afa55a14e30279026e59a033522877b70b74bfc000e276</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">228ef7e0a080de70652e3e0d1eab44f92f6280494c6ba98455111053701d3759</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">0e4246409cdad59e57c159c7cc4d75319edf7d197bc010174c76fe1257c3a68e</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">90f50d723bf38a267f5196e22ba22584a1c84d719b501237f43d10117d972843</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">4c008ac5c07d1573a98eb87bffe64e9c9e946de63b40df3f686881cf0698eef7</span></li>

</ul>
<h3><a id="post-132125-_7kq9eyonp7rk"></a>Advanced Port Scanner</h3>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">d0c1662ce239e4d288048c0e3324ec52962f6ddda77da0cb7af9c1d9c2f1e2eb</span></li>
</ul>
<h3><a id="post-132125-_xycfqn41vnje"></a>.NET Tool</h3>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">40126ae71b857dd22db39611c25d3d5dd0e60316b72830e930fba9baf23973ce</span></li>
</ul>

<ul>
<li><a href="https://www.computerweekly.com/news/366552075/BianLian-ransomware-gang-holds-Save-the-Children-hostage" target="_blank" rel="noopener">BianLian ransomware gang holds Save the Children hostage</a> – Computer Weekly, by TechTarget</li>
